To create this UI with an `AnnotatedString` in Jetpack Compose, you can use `ClickableText` (or `Text`) and `buildAnnotatedString` with inline styling. However, since you want a **background on only a part** of the string (\"confident, clear, and fluent\"), you’ll need to combine `AnnotatedString` for inline text styling with a `drawBehind` or overlay a background for just that span.\n\nJetpack Compose does **not natively support backgrounds on partial text via AnnotatedString** (as of now), but here\u0027s a popular technique:\n\n- Use `AnnotatedString` for bold, color, etc.\n- Isolate the highlighted text and place it in a `Box` with a background modifier.\n- Use a `Row` to compose the styles inline visually.\n\n**Here\u0027s how you can do it:**\n\n```kotlin\n@Composable\nfun HighlightedText() {\n Row(\n verticalAlignment \u003d Alignment.CenterVertically\n ) {\n Text(\n text \u003d \"become a more \",\n color \u003d Color.White,\n fontWeight \u003d FontWeight.Bold,\n fontSize \u003d 24.sp\n )\n Box(\n modifier \u003d Modifier\n .background(Color(0xFF215D36), shape \u003d RoundedCornerShape(4.dp))\n .border(width \u003d 2.dp, color \u003d Color(0xFF479565), shape \u003d RoundedCornerShape(4.dp))\n .padding(horizontal \u003d 8.dp, vertical \u003d 2.dp)\n ) {\n Text(\n text \u003d \"confident, clear, and fluent\",\n color \u003d Color.White,\n fontWeight \u003d FontWeight.Bold,\n fontSize \u003d 20.sp\n )\n }\n }\n Row(verticalAlignment \u003d Alignment.CenterVertically) {\n Text(\n text \u003d \"speaker.\",\n color \u003d Color.White,\n fontWeight \u003d FontWeight.Bold,\n fontSize \u003d 24.sp\n )\n Spacer(Modifier.width(8.dp))\n Text(text \u003d \"\", fontSize \u003d 18.sp)\n }\n}\n```\n\n---\n\n### If You Insist on AnnotatedString Only\n\nYou can set font, color, and weight—**but not backgrounds around substrings**. Here’s what that would look like (no background box):\n\n```kotlin\nval annotatedString \u003d buildAnnotatedString {\n withStyle(SpanStyle(color \u003d Color.White, fontWeight \u003d FontWeight.Bold, fontSize \u003d 24.sp)) {\n append(\"become a more \")\n }\n withStyle(SpanStyle(color \u003d Color.White, fontWeight \u003d FontWeight.Bold, fontSize \u003d 20.sp /*, background \u003d ... won\u0027t work here*/)) {\n append(\"confident, clear, and fluent\")\n }\n}\nText(text \u003d annotatedString)\n```\n\n---\n\n### **Best Result:** \nUse the **first approach** with `Row` \u0026 `Box` for that proper highlighted background effect.\n\nLet me know if you need a version for a vertical arrangement or want the code in a specific composable.**\n\nAdd these imports if not already present:\n```kotlin\nimport android.Manifest\nimport androidx.compose.runtime.LaunchedEffect\nimport androidx.compose.runtime.rememberCoroutineScope\nimport androidx.activity.compose.rememberLauncherForActivityResult\nimport androidx.activity.result.contract.ActivityResultContracts\n```\n\n---\n\n**Step 3: Modify your composable to request the permission and get the callback:**\n\nAdd the permission logic in your `OnboardingRecordingScreen`:\n\n```kotlin\n@Composable\nfun OnboardingRecordingScreen(\n modifier: Modifier \u003d Modifier,\n onPermissionResult: (Boolean) -\u003e Unit \u003d {}\n) {\n var recordingState by remember { mutableStateOf(RecordingState.IDLE) }\n var permissionRequested by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }\n \n // --- Permission Launcher ---\n val audioPermissionLauncher \u003d rememberLauncherForActivityResult(\n contract \u003d ActivityResultContracts.RequestPermission()\n ) { isGranted: Boolean -\u003e\n onPermissionResult(isGranted)\n if (isGranted) {\n recordingState \u003d RecordingState.PLAYING\n } else {\n // Optionally handle denial\n recordingState \u003d RecordingState.IDLE\n }\n }\n // --------------------------\n\n Scaffold(\n containerColor 20.dp)\n .padding(bottom \u003d 50.dp)\n .align(Alignment.BottomCenter)\n ) {\n // ...existing text...\n RecordingButton(\n state \u003d recordingState,\n onClick \u003d {\n if (recordingState \u003d\u003d RecordingState.IDLE \u0026\u0026 !permissionRequested) {\n permissionRequested \u003d true\n audioPermissionLauncher.launch(Manifest.permission.RECORD_AUDIO)\n } else if (recordingState Below is a way to create a common audio recording class for Android using Kotlin, which exposes two suspend functions: `onRecord()` to start recording and `onStop()` to stop, returning the recording as a ByteArray.\n\nThis helper uses [MediaRecorder](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/media/MediaRecorder) to record audio to a temporary file, which is then read as a ByteArray when stopped. \n\n**Note:** \n- For best use in Jetpack Compose, make sure you invoke the suspend functions appropriately (for example, inside a coroutine scope).\n- The class ensures all resources are released.\n- Don’t forget `RECORD_AUDIO` permission.\n\n---\n\n```kotlin\nimport android.content.Context\nimport android.media.MediaRecorder\nimport kotlinx.coroutines.Dispatchers\nimport kotlinx.coroutines.withContext\nimport java.io.File\n\nclass AudioRecorder(private val context: Context) {\n\n private var recorder: MediaRecorder? \u003d null\n private var audioFile: File? \u003d null\n\n suspend fun onRecord() \u003d withContext(Dispatchers.IO) {\n // Prepare temp audio file\n audioFile \u003d File.createTempFile(\"audio_record_\", \".m4a\", context.cacheDir)\n recorder \u003d MediaRecorder().apply {\n setAudioSource(MediaRecorder.AudioSource.MIC)\n setOutputFormat(MediaRecorder.OutputFormat.MPEG_4)\n setAudioEncoder(MediaRecorder.AudioEncoder.AAC)\n setOutputFile(audioFile!!.absolutePath)\n prepare()\n start()\n }\n }\n\n suspend fun onStop(): ByteArray? \u003d withContext(Dispatchers.IO) {\n try {\n recorder?.apply {\n stop()\n release()\n }\n recorder \u003d null\n // Read bytes from temp file\n val bytes \u003d audioFile?.readBytes()\n audioFile?.delete()\n audioFile \u003d null\n return@withContext bytes\n } catch (e: Exception) {\n e.printStackTrace()\n return@withContext null\n }\n }\n}\n```\n\n---\n\n### **How to use in Composable/VM:**\n\n```kotlin\nval audioRecorder \u003d remember { AudioRecorder(context) }\n// To start recording\nLaunchedEffect(Unit) { audioRecorder.onRecord() }\n// To stop and get bytes\nLaunchedEffect(Unit) { val audioBytes \u003d audioRecorder.onStop() }\n```\n\n---\n\n**You can now use this class wherever you need audio capture.** \nIf you want a callback-based (not suspend-based) approach, that can also be added! kotlinx.coroutines.flow.StateFlow\nimport kotlinx.coroutines.isActive\nimport kotlinx.coroutines.launch\nimport java.io.File\n\nclass AudioRecorder(private val context: Context) {\n\n private var recorder: MediaRecorder? \u003d null\n private var audioFile: File? \u003d null\n private var amplitudeJob: Job? \u003d null\n\n // Expose amplitude as a StateFlow\n private val _amplitude \u003d MutableStateFlow(0)\n val amplitude: StateFlow\u003cInt\u003e get() \u003d _amplitude\n\n suspend fun onRecord() {\n withContext(Dispatchers.IO) {\n audioFile \u003d File.createTempFile(\"audio_record_\", \".m4a\", context.cacheDir)\n recorder \u003d MediaRecorder().apply {\n setAudioSource(MediaRecorder.AudioSource.MIC)\n null\n _amplitude.value \u003d 0\n val bytes \u003d audioFile?.readBytes()\n audioFile?.delete()\n audioFile \u003d null\n return@withContext bytes\n } catch (e: Exception) {\n e.printStackTrace()\n _amplitude.value \u003d 0\n return@withContext null\n }\n }\n\n /**\n * Starts observing the current amplitude and emits it to the [amplitude] StateFlow.\n */\n private fun startAmplitudeUpdates() {\n amplitudeJob?.cancel()\n val scope \u003d CoroutineScope(Dispatchers.Default)\n amplitudeJob \u003d scope.launch {\n while (recorder !\u003d null \u0026\u0026 isActive) {\n // getMaxAmplitude returns 0 if called before start() or after stop()\n val currentAmplitude \u003d try {\n recorder?.maxAmplitude ?: 0\n } catch (e: Exception) {\n 0\n }\n _amplitude.value \u003d currentAmplitude\n delay(50) // update rate: every 50ms\n }\n }\n }\n}\n```\n\n---\n\n**Usage Example in Compose:**\n\n```kotlin\nval audioRecorder \u003d remember { AudioRecorder(context) }\nval amplitude by oscilloscope), you\u0027ll want to move away from a simple animated sine phase and instead animate a buffer of vertical points. As new amplitude values come in, old values shift out, mimicking real audio visualization.\n\n**Here’s how you can modify `AnimatedSineWave` to show a lively, random, and animated wave:**\n\n```kotlin\nimport androidx.compose.animation.core.*\nimport androidx.compose.foundation.Canvas\nimport androidx.compose.runtime.*\nimport androidx.compose.ui.Modifier\nimport androidx.compose.ui.geometry.Offset\nimport androidx.compose.ui.graphics.Color\nimport androidx.compose.ui.graphics.Path\nimport androidx.compose.ui.graphics.StrokeCap\nimport androidx.compose.ui.graphics.drawscope.Stroke\nimport kotlin.math.PI\nimport kotlin.math.sin\nimport kotlin.random.Random\n\n@Composable\nfun AnimatedRandomWave(\n modifier: Modifier \u003d Modifier,\n waveColor: Color \u003d Color.Cyan,\n amplitude: Float \u003d 40f,\n wavelength: Float \u003d 400f,\n speed: Float \u003d 200f,\n fps: Int \u003d 60,\n numPoints: Int \u003d 100\n) {\n val points \u003d remember { mutableStateListOf\u003cFloat\u003e() }\n val animDuration \u003d (1000f / fps).toLong()\n\n // Initialize points with some sine or random noise\n LaunchedEffect(Unit) {\n points.clear()\n for (i in 0 until numPoints) {\n points.add(amplitude * sin(2 * PI * i / wavelength).toFloat())\n }\n }\n\n // Animate by shifting points and injecting new random point\n LaunchedEffect(amplitude) {\n while (true) {\n points.removeAt(0)\n // New random wave: combine random and subtle sine for pleasant jitter\n val base \u003d amplitude * sin(2 * PI * (points.size + Random.nextFloat()) / wavelength).toFloat()\n val noise \u003d (Random.nextFloat() - 0.5f) * amplitude * 0.5f\n points.add(base + noise)\n delay(animDuration)\n }\n }\n\n Canvas(modifier \u003d modifier) {\n val width \u003d size.width\n val height \u003d size.height\n val step \u003d width / (numPoints - 1)\n val centerY \u003d height / 2\n\n val path \u003d Path()\n path.moveTo(0f, centerY + points.firstOrNull().orZero())\n\n points.forEachIndexed { i, value -\u003e\n path.lineTo(i * step, centerY + value)\n }\n\n drawPath(\n path \u003d path,\n color \u003d waveColor,\n style \u003d Stroke(width \u003d 3f, cap \u003d StrokeCap.Round)\n )\n }\n}\n\n// Extension for null safety\nprivate fun Float?.orZero(): Float \u003d this ?: 0f\n```\n\n**Usage:**\n```kotlin\nAnimatedRandomWave(\n modifier \u003d Modifier\n .fillMaxWidth()\n .height(200.dp),\n amplitude \u003d amplitude, // or provide your own animated amplitude\n waveColor \u003d Color.Cyan\n)\n```\n\n**What changed:**\n- The waveform is now a buffer of points, each animated with small random and smooth sine-based variations.\n- The line animates as a living, shining wave, not just sliding a sine phase.\n- It has a natural, organic feel resembling real waveform visualizations!\n\nLet me know if you want to tie the wave\u0027s \"height\" (amplitude) to your
```kotlin
@Composable
fun HomeMenuBar(selectedIndex: Int = 0, onMenuClick: (Int) -> Unit = {}) {
 val menuItems = listOf(
 MenuItem("analyse", Icons.Default.AutoAwesome, Color(0xFF473820)), // Gold/Brown (selected)
 MenuItem("practice", Icons.Default.ChatBubbleOutline, Color(0xFF202020)),
 MenuItem("history", Icons.Default.Menu, Color(0xFF202020)),
 MenuItem("progress", Icons.Default.ShowChart, Color(0xFF202020)),
 )
 Row(
 Modifier
 .fillMaxWidth()
 .background(Color(0xFF111110)),
 horizontalArrangement = Arrangement.SpaceEvenly,
 verticalAlignment = Alignment.CenterVertically
 ) {
 menuItems.forEachIndexed { index, item ->
 Column(
 modifier = Modifier
 .clickable { onMenuClick(index) }
 .padding(vertical = 16.dp),
 horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally,
 ) {
 Box(
 modifier = Modifier
 .size(90.dp)
 .background(
 color = if (index == selectedIndex) Color(0xFF473820) else Color(0xFF202020),
 shape = CircleShape
 ),
 contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
 ) {
 Icon(
 imageVector = item.icon,
 contentDescription = item.label,
 modifier = Modifier.size(42.dp),
 tint = Color.White
 )
 }
 Spacer(modifier = Modifier.height(12.dp))
 Text(
 text = item.label,
 color = Color(0xFFEEEEEE),
 fontSize = 18.sp,
 fontFamily = FontFamily.SansSerif
 )
 }
 }
 }
}

data class MenuItem(val label: String, val icon: ImageVector, val bgColor: Color)
```
